qas.question: Which section of the legislation was considered the most controversial?
What did critics claim that Title VII advocate?
Which Senator fought back against the criticism of Title VII?
Who was one of the key members that Humphrey managed to convince to support the bill?
What position of importance other than Senator did Everett Dirksen hold?
Which section of the legislation was considered the least controversial?
What did supporters claim that Title VII advocate?
Which Mayor fought back against the criticism of Title VII?
Who was one of the key members that Humphrey managed to convince to reject the bill?
What position of importance other than Mayor did Everett Dirksen hold?

context: <a0_0>Title VII<a0_0/> was perhaps the most controversial of the entire bill. Many conservatives accused it of advocating <a1_0>a <b6_0>de facto quota system<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and claimed unconstitutionality as it attempts to regulate the workplace. Minnesota Senator <a2_0><b7_0>Hubert Humphrey<b7_0/><a2_0/> corrected this notion: "there is nothing in [<b5_0>Title VII<b5_0/>] that will give power to the Commission to require hiring, firing, and promotion to meet a racial 'quota.' [. . .] Title VII is designed to encourage the hiring on basis of ability and qualifications, not race or religion." Title VII prohibits discrimination. Humphrey was the silent hero of the bill's passing through Congress. He pledged that the bill required no quotas, just nondiscrimination. Doing so, he convinced many pro-business Republicans, including <a4_0><b9_0>Senate Minority Leader<b9_0/><a4_0/> <a3_0><b8_0>Everett Dirksen<b8_0/><a3_0/> (IL) to support Title VII.:78–80
